title: Add timeout/fallback algorithm for building tree view
body:
Closes #299.

In Tree View, the `recurse_nodes` function travels down every possible path, leading to exploding complexity with certain recombining graphs. We can implement a very fast DFS traversal, but then we lose the nice expand/collapse functionality. Unfortunately I don't know an easy way to compute the number of paths in a graph (I think there's a big prize for that), so I'm solving this the old fashioned way: try the complicated method, and if it takes too long, fall back on the quick one.

Here's what happens:
1. The default timeout is 1 second (I thought that was a reasonable wait for most graphs)
2. We try to run the full recursion. If it finishes in less than 1 second, the resulting tree view has full expand/collapse functionality
3. But if the full recursion times out, then it falls back on a quick DFS recursion that will display a full tree, but can't be dynamically expanded
4. If a URL parameter `force_expand` is passed, then the timeout is removed and the system will compute the full recursion no matter how long it takes.

title: (Py3) bytes/string fix for encryption
body:
I hate to revisit #314 so quickly, but what worked on one Py3 machine is not working on another. This PR explicitly casts the Py3 `bytes` objects back to `str`.

The bytes objects being used here are part of the `python-future` compatibility suite and should not affect Py2 users at all (and don’t in any of my tests).

title: (Py3) implement comparison operators
body:
Something strange happened to my last PR -- a bad reset wiped it out -- so I'm splitting out the necessary functionality from the wishful ones. 

This PR makes tasks and dags comparable in Python 3 (Py3 ignores `__cmp__`, so it's impossible for two DAGs to be equal to each other in the `==` sense, much less any other comparison). It also supplies a `__hash__` implementation, which is required when providing a custom `__eq__` (otherwise both are based on `is`).

title: More instructions/warnings about using cryptography
body:
This PR is about making it easier for users to take advantage of @neovintage's great work in #267!

The problem is that existing users aren't given a clear path to enable encryption. The warning in #279 suggests that they should install the `cryptography` library, but that's not enough -- encryption only works if they also put a `fernet_key` in their `airflow.cfg` files. Airflow will create a default key for a fresh install, but anyone with an existing `airflow.cfg` file is out of luck unless they change it themselves -- and by definition, anyone seeing #279 already has an `airflow.cfg`!

So this PR does two things: if the user has `cryptography` installed but no `fernet_key` option, it prompts them to create an encryption key at import (and provides a helper function `generate_fernet_key()`). It also expands the warning from #279 to explain that just installing `cryptography` isn't enough, users must add the key.

New warning message:

```
In [1]: import airflow
WARNING:root:

Your system supports encrypted passwords for Airflow connections but is
currently storing them in plaintext! To turn on encryption, add a
"fernet_key" option to the "core" section of your airflow.cfg file,
like this:

    [core]
    fernet_key = <YOUR FERNET KEY>

Your airflow.cfg file is located at: /Users/jlowin/airflow/airflow.cfg.
If you need to generate a fernet key, you can run this code:

    from airflow.configuration import generate_fernet_key
    generate_fernet_key()
```

Updated UI message:
![screen shot 2015-08-25 at 4 04 48 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/153965/9477960/16fc39de-4b43-11e5-8699-cf8a4e72c342.png)

title: Obscure Py3 fixes / update DAG.pickle()
body:
This PR is a little odd and digs into some weird Python 3 idiosyncrasies. It started as a simple fix for the `dag.pickle()` method (which I think incorrectly referenced `DAG` instead of `DagModel`) but the DAG comparisons kept failing. 

Turns out Python 3 completely ignores  `__cmp__` and requires rich comparison operators instead (`__eq__`, `__lt__`, etc.). And if you implement `__eq__`, you have to also implement `__hash__`, which is when I remembered that in Python 3, `hash()` is randomized and is not stable across interpreters. Usually this only manifests as unexpected dict orderings, but here it would mean that unpickled DAGs would have different `hash` values from each other and from the original -- hardly good when we are even storing the hash in the DagPickle table!

So this PR does a few things:
1. replaces `__cmp__` for `DAG` and `BaseOperator` with rich comparison ops using the `functools.total_ordering` decorator to add missing ones. 
   
   Note: `__cmp__` didn't have a way to express "not equal" so it returned negative numbers which actually implied "less than". So to maintain compatibility, I put the comparison logic in `__lt__` rather than `__eq__`. This shouldn't have any practical impact but might look surprising.
2. precalculates a `hash` value for `DAG` and `BaseOperator`. By recalculating and storing the hash, unpickled DAGs are all guaranteed to have the same hash no matter what interpreter loads them. 
   
   This is far from a perfect solution but Python 3 has basically made it impossible to use hashes as a stable key, so at least this will work across versions. A better and more stable solution would be to define a unique combination of attributes and use their md5 digest as the hash value (for tasks, `task_id`, `dag_id`, and `type` should work; for DAGs, maybe `dag_id`, `start_date`, `end_date`, `owner` and the md5 hashes of all its tasks). I have NOT done that here, though.
3. Updates `DAG.pickle()` to work properly. This was the original goal.

title: Small convenience: guess PyOp name from callable
body:
When creating PythonOperators, I noticed I was frequently typing my function name twice: first as the `python_callable` and then as the `task_id`, which seems redundant. So this is a really simple convenience to try and set the `task_id` of a `PythonOperator` from the `python_callable` that was passed to it. Users can still pass `task_id` if they want, this just potentially cuts down on one step.

``` python
def my_long_task_id():
    pass

op = PythonOperator(
    dag=dag,
    python_callable= my_long_task_id)

op.task_id == 'my_long_task_id' # true
```

title: Making the dependency engine more flexible
body:
New `BaseOperator` parameter enables task triggers beyond "all directly upstream tasks succeeded", here are the new options:

```
:param trigger_rule: defines the rule by which dependencies are applied
        for the task to get triggered. Options are:
        ``{ all_success | all_failed | all_done | one_success |
        one_failed | dummy}``
        default is ``all_success``. Options can be set as string or
        using the constants defined in the static class
        ``airflow.utils.TriggerRule``
    :type trigger_rule: str
```

title: Add XCom (cross-communication) functionality
body:
Supersedes #232. 

Provides XCom objects and methods for passing messages/state between tasks. XCom values can be any pickleable object. Please see the `concepts` doc, `TaskInstance.xcom_push()` and `TaskInstance.xcom_pull()` docstrings, and `example_xcom.py` for more info.

``` python
    # inside a PythonOperator called 'pushing_task'
    def push_function(**context):
        context['ti'].xcom_push(key='sample XCom', value=v)

    # inside another PythonOperator
    def pull_function(**context):
        v = context['ti'].xcom_pull(task_ids='pushing_task')
```

title: Py3 debugging
body:
These seem to be some of the last blocks to running simple DAGs in Airflow on Python 3. It's very possible edge cases still exist, so Python 3 users will have to be vigilant and submit patches as they find them. For example, one of these fixes would only be an issue if the database had no rows, and then only because the result [None] was compared to an int... which is okay in Python 2 but not in Python 3. Ugh.

Also, it would be great if it were possible to run future testing in both Python 2 and Python 3 environments, since regressions can be introduced inadvertently.

title: Add functionality for storing/retrieving values
body:
Addresses #182 and also #170. Would love thoughts on utility/names, as well as any easier ways of getting the execution_date (see below).

The `TaskValue` class extends the idea of Variables without polluting the Variable namespace (I have a feeling people are using Variables for some specific purpose).

`TaskValues` are json-serialized values that are keyed by `task_id`, `dag_id`, and an arbitrary `key`. They can be recalled by matching on any (or all) of those fields. For example, `TaskValue.get(task_id='my_task')` would return the most recent value saved by any task called `my_task`, whereas `TaskValue.get(task_id='my_task', dag_id='my_dag')` would limit the query to only `my_task` run in `my_dag`. At least one of `task_id`, `dag_id`, or `key` must be passed.

In addition, the `execution_date` must be passed to make sure that values from the future aren't passed (this could happen, for example, during a backfill). If there's a better way to get the execution date, please let me know.

Example:

``` python
import airflow
from airflow.models import TaskValue
import datetime

default_args = {'owner': 'airflow'}

dag = airflow.DAG(
    'simple_dag',
    start_date=datetime.datetime(2015, 1, 1),
    default_args=default_args)

### These functions show how to set/get values from Python functions

# this function stores a value: [1, 2, 3]
def func_1(**kwargs):
    TaskValue.set(
        task_instance=kwargs['task_instance'],
        key='val from func 1',
        value=[1, 2, 3])

# this function recalls the value by key
def func_2(**kwargs):
    val = TaskValue.get(
        execution_date=kwargs['execution_date'],
        key='val from func 1')

    assert val == [1, 2, 3]

# this function recalls the value by task_id
def func_3(**kwargs):
    val = TaskValue.get(
        execution_date=kwargs['execution_date'],
        task_id='func_1')

    assert val == [1, 2, 3]

### This class shows how to use values in any Operator's execute() method
class MyOperator(airflow.models.BaseOperator):

    def execute(self, context):

        # set a value
        self.set_value(key='val from my op', value=[1, 2, 3], context=context)

        # recall the value
        val1 = self.get_value(key='val from my op', context=context)

        # recall the value from task 'func_1'
        val2 = self.get_value(task_id='func_1', context=context)

        assert val1 == [1, 2, 3]
        assert val2 == [1, 2, 3]


# Set up the DAG

f1 = airflow.operators.PythonOperator(
    task_id='func_1', provide_context=True, dag=dag, python_callable=func_1)
f2 = airflow.operators.PythonOperator(
    task_id='func_2', provide_context=True, dag=dag, python_callable=func_2)
f3 = airflow.operators.PythonOperator(
    task_id='func_3', provide_context=True, dag=dag, python_callable=func_3)
f4 = MyOperator(task_id='func_4', dag=dag)

f1.set_downstream([f2, f3, f4])
```

title: Enhancements to ExternalTaskSensor
body:
- param allowed_states: list of allowed states, default is `['success']`
- param execution_delta: time difference with the previous execution to look at, the default is the same execution_date as the current task. For yesterday, use [positive!] datetime.timedelta(days=1)

title: Extend jdbc functionality
body:
- Adjust web ui to allow definition of jdbc connections
- Use host column for jdbc connection url
- Use connection models extra for storing jdbc driver path and classname
- Use connections extra_dejson to create the jdbc connection
- Use DbApiHook as a base for JdbcHook
- Make JdbcOperator consistent with other Db ops by using run

title: [cli] improved datetime parsing for the "clear" command
body:
Test plan:
- Create a dag and a dummy task with schedule_interval 1 hour.
- Let it run for a couple of hours
- Clear tasks with the following command:
  airflow clear test_dag -s "2015-07-24 15:00" -e "2015-07-24 18:00"
- Check that the tasks are cleared as expected.

title: Add smtp_starttls flag to config
body: I need to work with a mail server that does not support STARTTLS.  This PR adds a config file setting (defaulting to True) to decide when to activate STARTTLS.

title: Generalize presto check operator to work for other backends
body:
This PR attempts to generalize the PrestoCheckOperator family so it can be used with other backends besides Presto.

There are two parts to this...
1. the first part creates a baseSqlHook to ensure that other hooks can easily be used in this CheckOperator
2. the second part separates out the check implementation from presto.

I decided to make the operators an abstract class so we can continue the pattern of not instantiating the hook until we are going to execute, rather than creating them in the constructor. Alternatively, I could have passed in a hook and a list of hook parameters but that felt pretty icky.

I had some problems running the tests on my local machine -- I'm not sure if there are some other instructions that are needed but my hive tests and other external dependencies were failing.

title: Send custom message with email alerts.
body:
Added an option to send custom email message. This can be used to provide more context to the receivers of these emails, eg by giving them actionable instructions are by linking them to a help center page.

Also, removed unused parameter.

Test plan
- Couldn't get my local changes to run (it would always run the pip-installed airflow instead) tested my changes by copypasting into ipython instead.
